single_stimulus.title: Mitchell-Schaeffer (1 Stimulus)
single_stimulus.desc: Simulates the response of a single electrical stimulus in a cardiac cell.

multiple_stimuli.title: Mitchell-Schaeffer (8 Stimuli)
multiple_stimuli.desc: Observes cellular response to a series of stimuli with a fixed interval.

s1_s2.title: S1-S2 Protocol
s1_s2.desc: Standard protocol to investigate cardiac tissue refractoriness and vulnerability.

restitution_curve.title: Restitution Curve
restitution_curve.desc: Analyzes the relationship between coupling interval and action potential duration using different protocols.

fhn.title: FitzHugh-Nagumo
fhn.desc: Simplified model of cardiac excitability in one dimension.

ms_1d.title: Mitchell-Schaeffer
ms_1d.desc: Mitchell-Schaeffer extended to a spatial dimension.

model_2d.title: Mitchell-Schaeffer 2D Model
model_2d.desc: Simulates 2D wave propagation, allowing S1-S2 protocols and fibrosis inclusion.

single.desc: This simulation uses the Mitchell-Schaeffer model to describe the cardiac action potential. It is a two-variable model simulating the behavior of a single cell.
single.eq_v: dv/dt = (h * v² * (1 - v)) / τ_in - v / τ_out + I_stim
single.method: Equations are solved numerically using the Forward Euler method for voltage (V) and Rush-Larsen for the gating variable (h).

multiple.protocol_desc: Instead of a single pulse, a sequence of stimuli is applied. The BCL (Basic Cycle Length) parameter defines the time interval between the start of one stimulus and the next.

s1s2.protocol_desc: The S1-S2 protocol is a standard method in electrophysiology to measure the refractory period.
s1s2.s1_desc: S1: A sequence of stimuli to drive the cell to a steady state.
s1s2.s2_desc: S2: A single premature stimulus applied after the last S1.

restitution.what_is_desc: It describes the relationship between the Action Potential Duration (APD) and the preceding Diastolic Interval (DI). The slope of this curve is crucial for predicting arrhythmias.
restitution.apd_def: APD: Time for voltage to repolarize 90% (APD90).

s1s2.title: Mitchell-Schaeffer
s1s2.desc: Uses the original Mitchell-Schaeffer model with the S1-S2 protocol. The inward current is proportional to voltage squared.
s1s2.eq_h: dh/dt depends on τ_open and τ_close via Rush-Larsen
steps: The cell is stimulated with an S1 sequence at a fixed BCL to reach steady state.
An S2 pulse is applied with a variable interval after the last S1.
APD of S2 and corresponding DI are measured.
The process repeats, reducing the S2 interval.

mms.title: Modified Mitchell-Schaeffer (MMS)
mms.desc: The MMS model alters the inward current equation (J_in) to enable robust mathematical analysis and calculation of an analytical curve.
mms.eq_h: dh/dt depends on τ_open and τ_close via Rush-Larsen
steps: Uses the same S1-S2 protocol described previously.
The main difference lies in the cellular model equation.
Allows direct comparison with a theoretical analytical curve.

dynamic.title: Dynamic Protocol
dynamic.desc: Uses the standard Mitchell-Schaeffer model but with a continuous stimulation protocol (Dynamic Pacing), which is more physiologically relevant as it includes cardiac memory.
dynamic.eq_h: dh/dt depends on τ_open and τ_close via Rush-Larsen
steps: Simulation starts with a long BCL (CI1).
The cell is stimulated 'nbeats' times at this rate. The APD of the last beat is measured.
The BCL is shortened (CIinc), and the process repeats without long pauses.
This continues until BCL reaches the final value (CI0).

bistable.desc: A single-variable reaction-diffusion model used to demonstrate wavefront formation and bistable behavior (two stable states: v=0 and v=1).
bistable.method: Space: 2nd Order Finite Differences. Time: 4th Order Runge-Kutta (RK4).

fhn.desc: Two-variable model (v and w) simplifying action potential dynamics. v is potential, w is recovery.
fhn.reentry: Reentry simulation creates a broken/spiral wave that propagates in a self-sustaining manner.
fhn.method: Space: 2nd Order Finite Differences. Time: 4th Order Runge-Kutta (RK4).

ms1d.desc: 1D version of the Mitchell-Schaeffer model. Adds a spatial diffusion term to allow wave propagation.
ms1d.eq: ∂v/∂t = k * (∂²v/∂x²) + (h * v² * (1 - v)) / τ_in - v / τ_out + I_stim
ms1d.method: Space: 2nd Order Finite Differences. Time: Forward Euler for voltage (v) and Rush-Larsen for gate (h).

ms2d.desc: Simulates wave propagation in 2D tissue. Conduction depends on fiber orientation (angle), with different conductivities in longitudinal and transverse directions.
ms2d.eq: ∂v/∂t = ∇ · (D ∇v) + I_ion. D is the diffusion tensor.
ms2d.fibrosis_desc: Fibrosis is simulated by creating regions where conductivity is reduced isotropically. It can be Compact (random across domain) or Diffuse (restricted area).
ms2d.method: Space: 2nd Order Finite Differences. Time: Forward Euler for voltage (v) and Rush-Larsen for gate (h).
